sen.j: 元弘3年に後醍醐天皇が伯耆船上山で挙兵した際、鎌倉幕府の有力御家人として幕府軍を率いて上洛したが、丹波篠村八幡宮で反幕府の兵を挙げ、六波羅探題を滅ぼした。
sen.e: In 1333 (Genko 3), when the Emperor Go-Daigo had raised an army at Mt. Senjosan in Hoki Province, Takauji, the powerful vassal of the Kamakura shogunate, was sent to Kyoto leading the main armies of the shogunate to put down the rebellion, but he switched his side and gathered an army against the shogunate at Shinomura Hachimangu in Tamba Province to capture Rokuhara Tandai.

sen.j: 幕府滅亡の勲功第一とされ、後醍醐天皇の諱・尊治（たかはる）の御一字を賜り、名を尊氏に改める。
sen.e: His achievements were evaluated by Emperor Go-Daigo, and he was awarded the letter (尊), which came from the emperor's real name Takaharu (尊治), so he changed the letter in his name from "高氏" to "尊氏".

sen.j: 後醍醐専制による建武の新政が次第に支持を失っていく中、東下して中先代の乱を鎮圧した後、鎌倉に留まり独自の政権を樹立する構えを見せた。
sen.e: While the despotic Kemmu restoration by Emperor Go-Daigo had been losing support, Takauji traveled to the east to suppress the Nakasendai Rebellion, and stayed in Kamakura to try to build his own government.

sen.j: これにより朝廷との関係が悪化し、上洛して一時は後醍醐を比叡山へ追いやったが、後醍醐勢力の反攻により一旦は九州へ落ち延びる。
sen.e: Because of this, the relationship between Takauji and the imperial court came to an impasse, and he returned to Kyoto, driving the Emperor Go-Daigo out to Mt. Hiei. However, the Emperor's army made a counterattack and Takauji fled to Kyushu temporarily.

sen.e: He reentered Kyoto and established a new samurai government called Muromachi Shogunate, being appointed Seii Taishogun by Grand Emperor (Retired Emperor) Kogon and Empror Komyo.

sen.e: After he established Muromachi Shogunate, he and his brother Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA divided the power between them, but in later years discord between them increased to the Kanno Disturbance.

sen.j: 直義の死により乱は終息したが、その後も南朝など反幕勢力の平定を継続し、統治の安定に努めた。
sen.e: The disturbance subsided by the death of Tadayoshi, but even after that Takauji had to keep fighting against his enemies such as the Southern Court forces to maintain his government.

sen.j: 後醍醐が崩御（死去）した後はその菩提を弔うため天竜寺を建立している。

sen.j: （後醍醐）天皇に叛旗を翻したことから明治以降は逆賊として位置づけられていたが、第二次大戦後は肯定的に再評価されているように、歴史観の変遷によってその人物像が大きく変化している。
sen.e: Because of his rebellion against the emperor, people had branded him as a traitor since Meiji era, but after World War II they began to look at him more positively, which illustrates how much the historical point of view affects the way we look at the people in history.

sen.e: Kamakura shogunate ordered Takauji, who had been a powerful vassal, to help the shogunate, and he joined the battles at Kasasagi where the emperor was based and the Shimoakasaka Castle in which Masashige KUSUNOKI was based.

sen.j: このとき、父・貞氏が没した直後であり高氏は派兵を辞退するが、幕府は妻子を人質として重ねて派兵を命じた。
sen.e: The incident had taken place just after his father's death, so Takauji at first had refused his help to the shogunate, but the Kamakura shognate took his wife and children as hostages to make Takauji follow its order.

sen.j: 幕府軍の攻撃の結果、天皇をはじめとして倒幕計画に関わった日野俊基・円観などの公家や僧侶が多数、幕府に捕縛され、天皇は翌年隠岐島に流された（元弘の乱）。
sen.e: As a result of the attack against the emperor made by the shogunate, the emperor and his followers such as Toshimoto HINO and Enkan were captured, and the following year Emperor Go-Daigo was exiled to Oki Islands. (Genko Rebellion)

sen.j: 翌元弘3年/正慶2年（1333年）後醍醐天皇は隠岐島を脱出して船上山に篭城した。
sen.e: In the following year, Emperor Go-Daigo escaped from Oki Islands, and raised an army at Mt. Senjosan.

sen.j: 高氏は再び幕命を受け、西国の討幕勢力を鎮圧するために名越高家とともに上洛した。

sen.j: 名越高家が赤松則村に討たれたことを機として、後醍醐天皇の綸旨を受けていた高氏は天皇方につくことを決意し、同年4月29日、所領の丹波国篠村八幡宮（京都府亀岡市）で反幕府の兵を挙げた。
sen.e: Takaie was killed by Norimura AKAMATSU, which made Takauji decide to side with the emperor. On April 29th of the same year, he raised an army against the shogunate at Shinomura Hachimangu (present Kameoka City, Kyoto) in Tamba Province.

sen.j: 諸国に多数の軍勢催促状を発し、近江国の佐々木道誉などの御家人を従えて入京し、同年5月7日に六波羅探題を滅亡させた。
sen.e: Takauji gathered forces from various provinces, and entered Kyoto followed by vassals such as Doyo SASAKI from Omi Province, and then succeeded in destroying Rokuhara Tandai on May 7th, 1333.

sen.j: 同時期に上野国の御家人である新田義貞も挙兵しており、高氏の嫡子で鎌倉から脱出した千寿王（後の足利義詮）を奉じて鎌倉へ進軍し、幕府を滅亡させた。
sen.e: At about the same time, Yoshisada NITTA, vassal of Kozuke Province, also gathered an army, and destroyed the shogunate, taking Takauji's heir Senjuo (later called Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA), who had escaped from Kamakura, with him.

sen.j: 高氏は鎌倉陥落後に細川和氏・細川頼春・細川師氏の兄弟を派遣して義貞を上洛させ、鎌倉を足利方に掌握させている。
sen.e: After the Kamakura shogunate was crumbled, Takauji ordered Kazuuji HOSOKAWA, Yoriharu HOSOKAWA and Morouji HOSOKAWA to make Yoshisada NITTA return to Kyoto, and let the Ashikaga clan rule Kamakura.

sen.j: 建武 (日本)元年（1334年）、尊氏は、実子恒良親王を皇太子としたい後醍醐天皇の寵姫阿野廉子と結び、後醍醐天皇とも確執していた護良親王を捕縛し鎌倉の直義のもとに幽閉させる。

sen.e: Shin'ichi Sato called such conditions diarchy by Takauji, who held a military power in the lord-and-vassal relationship, and Tadayoshi, who controlled over the judicial functions of the regime, in his essay 'Muromachi Bakufu' in "Iawanami Koza Nihon Rekishi vol.7" (Iawanami Publishing, 1963) and explained that the potentiality of the shogun's dual power which had continued since Kamakura Shogunate, came to appear.

sen.j: 二元化した権力は徐々に幕府内部の対立を呼び起こしていき、高師直らの反直義派と直義派の対立として現れていく。
sen.e: The dual power gradually led to a conflict between anti-Tadayoshi group represented by Ko no Moronao, and Tadayoshi group in the government.
The dual power gradually led to a conflict between anti-Tadayoshi group represented by KO no Moronao, and the Tadayoshi group in the government.

sen.j: この対立はついに観応の擾乱と呼ばれる内部抗争に発展した。
sen.e: This conflict finally raised an internal split called Kanno Disturbance.

sen.j: 尊氏は当初、中立的立場を取っていたが、師直派に擁立されてしまう。
sen.e: At first Takauji took a neutral stance on it, but he came to side with Moronao's group.

sen.j: 正平 (日本)4年/貞和5年（1349年）、襲撃を受けた直義が逃げ込んだ尊氏邸を師直の兵が包囲し、直義の引退を求める事件が発生した。
sen.e: In 1349, Moronao demanded Tadayoshi's retirement from politics, surrounding Takauji's castle in which Tadayoshi had sheltered.

sen.j: 直義は出家し政務を退くこととなったが、直義の排除には師直・尊氏の間で了解があり、積極的に意図されていたとする説がある。
sen.e: Tadayoshi became a priest and lost his power, but it is said that Moronao and Takauji made a prearrangement to exclude Tadayoshi.

sen.j: 尊氏は直義に代わって政務を担当させるため嫡男義詮を鎌倉から呼び戻し、代わりに次男足利基氏を下して鎌倉公方とし、東国統治のための鎌倉府を設置した。
sen.e: While Takauji called back his heir Yoshiakira from Kamakura to put him in charge of political affairs instead of Tadayoshi, he sent his second son Motouji ASHIKAGA to Kamakura in return and set the Kamakurafu to rule the eastern provinces, appointing Motouji Kamakura kubo.
sen.cmt: 当時の政治の中心は、土地所有をめぐる争いを裁くことでした。

sen.j: 直義の引退後、尊氏庶子で直義猶子の足利直冬が九州で直義派として勢力を拡大していたため、正平5年/観応元年（1350年）、尊氏は直冬討伐のために中国地方へ遠征した。
sen.e: After Tadayoshi's retreat, Takauji's illegitimate and also Tadayoshi's adopted son Tadafuyu ASHIKAGA was enlarging his power as a member of the Tadayoshi's side in Kyushu, so Takauji made an expedition to Chugoku District to kill Tadafuyu in 1350.

sen.j: すると直義は京都を脱出して南朝方に付き、桃井直常、畠山国清ら一部の譜代の武将たちもこれに従った。
sen.e: Then Tadayoshi escaped from Kyoto and sided with the Southern Court, followed by a few of the devoted military commanders such as Tadatsune MOMONOI and Kunikiyo HATAKEYAMA.

sen.e: When Tadayoshi's army grew stronger, Yoshiakira became powerless and fled from Kyoto. Takauji was also defeated by Tadayoshi's army at Uchidehama in Settsu Province (present Nishinomiya City, Hyogo Prefecture).

sen.j: 尊氏は高兄弟の出家を条件に直義と和睦し、正平6年/観応2年（1351年）に和議が成立した。
sen.e: Takauji sought reconciliation with Tadayoshi on condition that the KO brothers would become priests, and they came to an agreement in 1351.

sen.j: 高兄弟は護送中に上杉能憲により謀殺されている。

The KO brothers were assassinated by Yoshinori UESUGI while they were under escort.

sen.j: 直義は義詮の補佐として政務に復帰した。
sen.e: Tadayoshi became Yoshiakira's assistant and got involved in political affairs again.

sen.j: 尊氏・義詮は佐々木道誉や赤松則祐の謀反を名目として近江・播磨へ出陣し、実際には直義・直冬追討を企てて南朝方と和睦交渉を行なった。
sen.e: Takauji and Yoshiakira marched to Harima Province on the ostensible purpose to put down the revolt plotted by Doyo SASAKI and Sokuyu (Norisuke) AKAMATSU, but in reality they attempted a reconciliation with the Southern Court, conspiring to kill Tadayoshi and Tadafuyu.

sen.j: この動きに対して直義は北陸方面へ脱出して鎌倉へ逃げた。
sen.e: Sensing this conspiracy, Tadayoshi fled to the northern area and reached Kamakura.

sen.j: 尊氏と南朝の和睦は同年10月に成立し、これを正平一統という。

sen.j: 平行して尊氏は直義を追って東海道を進み、駿河薩捶山（静岡県静岡市清水区）、相模早川尻（神奈川県小田原市）などでの戦闘で撃ち破り、直義を捕らえて鎌倉に幽閉した。
sen.e: At the same time, Takauji chased Tadayoshi along the Tokaido, and defeated him at the battles of Mt. Satsutamayama in Suruga Province (Present Shimizu Ward, Shimizu City, Shizuoka Prefecture) and Hayakawajiri in Sagami Province (present Odawara City, Kanagawa Prefecture). Takauji captured Tadayoshi and confined him in Kamakura.

sen.j: 直義は、正平7年/観応3年（1352年）2月に急死した。

sen.j: その直後に宗良親王、新田義興・新田義宗、北条時行などの南朝方から襲撃された尊氏は武蔵国へ退却するが、すぐさま反撃し関東の南朝勢力を制圧すると、京都へ戻った。
sen.e: Soon after Tadayoshi's death, being attacked by the Southern Court forces represented by Prince Muneyoshi, Yoshioki NITTA, Yoshimune NITTA and Tokiyuki HOJO, Takauji retreated to Musashi Province, but soon returned to Kyoto defeating the Southern forces.

sen.j: その後足利直冬が京都へ侵攻するが、結局直冬は九州へ去る。

sen.j: 正平9年/文和3年（1354年）にも京都を南朝に一時奪われるが、翌年奪還した。
sen.e: In 1354, Kyoto was retaken by the Southern Court temporarily, but retaken by Takauji the following year.

sen.j: 尊氏は自ら直冬討伐を企てるが、正平13年/延文3年4月30日（1358年）、背中に出来た癰（よう、腫物）のため、京都二条万里小路邸にて死去した。
sen.e: He plotted to kill Tadafuyu, but died of a tumor on his back at the palace of Made'nokoji in Nijo, Kyoto, on April 30th, 1358 (Shohei 13/Enbun 3).

sen.j: 享年54。

sen.j: 『梅松論』などによると、尊氏は後醍醐に背いて朝敵となったことを悔やんで一時は出家を宣言したり、合戦で苦戦した際には切腹すると言い出すなどの記述があり、佐藤進一は尊氏を躁鬱病ではないかと推測している。
sen.e: According to "Baishoron", Takauji regretted having turned against Emperor Go-Daigo, and he was telling temporarily that he would become a priest. He also announced that he would kill himself when he was in hard-fought battles, so Shin'ichi SATO took these descriptions into consideration, and presumed that Takauji might have been a manic depressive.

sen.j: 個人的に親交のあった夢窓疎石は、尊氏の徳を評価した文章を残している。

sen.j: 尊氏は傘下の武将たちへの恩賞を惜しむことがなく、そのことが苦境に立たされても常に武将たちの支持が得られた理由だとする見解もある。
sen.e: Takauji was willing to allot lands to his military commanders, which is considered one of the reasons why he had constantly been supported by them when he was in difficult situations.

sen.j: 尊氏を逆賊とする評価は、江戸時代に徳川光圀が創始した水戸学に始まる。
sen.e: It was the Mitogaku originated by Mitsukuni TOKUGAWA that started to consider Takauji as a traitor in the Edo period.

sen.j: 水戸学は朱子学名分論の影響を強く受けており、皇統の正統性を重視していた。
sen.e: Mitogaku was strongly influenced by Shushigaku Meibunron, and emphasized the validity of the Imperial line.
Mitogaku was strongly influenced by Shushigaku Meibunron, and emphasized the validity of the Imperial line.

sen.j: そのため、正統な天皇（後醍醐天皇）を放逐した尊氏は逆賊として否定的に描かれることとなった。
sen.e: Because of this, Takauji, who exiled the authentic emperor (Go-Daigo), was described in a negative way as a traitor.
Because of this, Takauji, who exiled the authentic emperor (Go-Daigo), was described in a negative way as a traitor.
Because of this, Takauji, who exiled the authentic emperor (Go-Daigo), was described in a negative way as a traitor.

sen.j: 水戸学に発する尊氏観はその後も継承され、尊王思想が高まった幕末期には尊皇攘夷論者によって等持院の尊氏・義詮・義満3代の木像が梟首される事件も発生している。
sen.e: Mitogaku's view of Takauji was inherited by the later generations, and in the late Tokugawa period when Sonno-Joi (Revere the Emperor, Expel the Barbarian) culminated, heads of the wooden statues of Takauji, Yoshiakira and Yoshimitsu (ASHIKAGA) in Toji-in were hanged.

Mitogaku's view of Takauji was inherited by the later generations, and in the late Tokugawa period when Sonno-Joi (Revere the Emperor, Expel the Barbarian) culminated, the heads of wooden statues of Takauji, Yoshiakira and Yoshimitsu (ASHIKAGA) in Toji-in were pilloried.

Mitogaku's view of Takauji was inherited by the later generations, and in the late Tokugawa period when Sonno-Joi (Revere the Emperor, Expel the Barbarian) culminated, the heads of wooden statues of Takauji, Yoshiakira and Yoshimitsu (ASHIKAGA) in Toji-in were pilloried.

sen.j: 明治時代になると、明治政府の立場から天皇を中心とする国民国家を建設するため、国家主義的な歴史観が構築されていったが、それは大政奉還・王政復古を正当化する歴史観であり、そのため大化の改新・建武の中興・明治維新が最も重要な改革に位置づけられた。
sen.e: After the Meiji period, the Meiji government sought for establishing the nation-state which set the emperor in the center of the nation. This produced the nationalistic view of history, which justified Taisei Hokan and Osei Fukko, so Taika Reforms, Kemmu no Chuko (=Kemmu restoration) and Meiji Restoration were ranked as the most important restoration.
sen.cmt: 大政奉還の対訳からReturn of Political Rule of the Emperor削除、王政復古の対訳からRestoration of Imperial Rule削除、明治維新の対訳からMeiji Ishin削除

sen.j: 明治中期までは近代的歴史学による実証的研究から後醍醐天皇・南朝の正統性はそれほど強調されていなかったが、明治40年代に入り、南北朝正閏論を経て、後醍醐天皇・南朝の正統性が強く主張されていき、それに伴って尊氏に対する否定的な評価が確定することとなった。
sen.e: Until mid Meiji period, source-based study of modern historiography did not emphasize the validity of Emperor Go-Daigo (the Southern Court), but at around Meiji 40 when the Nambokucho Seijunron arose, the validity of Emperor Go-Daigo (the Southern Court) came to be stressed, creating a negative evaluation of Takauji.

Until mid Meiji period, source-based study of modern history did not emphasize the validity of Emperor Go-Daigo (the Southern Court), but at around 1907 40 when the Nambokucho Seijunron arose, the validity of Emperor Go-Daigo came to be stressed, creating a negative evaluation of Takauji.

sen.j: 戦前の国定教科書には「天皇に弓を引いた逆臣」と書かれており、斎藤実内閣の中島久万吉商工大臣が尊氏を礼賛した文章を書いたために辞任する事件も起こった。
sen.e: According to an authorized textbook written before WWII, Takauji was "a traitor who released an arrow against the Emperor", and Kumakichi NAKAJIMA, a member of the Makoto SAITO Cabinet, was forced to retire because he had praised Takauji in his writing.

According to an authorized textbook written before WWII, Takauji was "a traitor who released an arrow against the Emperor", and Kumakichi NAKAJIMA, a member of the Makoto SAITO Cabinet, was forced to retire because he had praised Takauji in his writing.

sen.j: 戦後になると、国家主義的な歴史観が大きく後退し実証主義的な歴史研究が進展したことに伴い、尊氏の再評価が進められた。
sen.e: After WWII, the nationalistic view of history became obsolete, and the source-based study of history made progress, revaluating Takauji.
After WWII, the nationalistic view of history became obsolete, and the source-based study of history made progress on reevaluating Takauji.

sen.j: 佐藤進一による主従制的支配者としての尊氏の評価はその一例であり、これは武家政権に関する研究が大きく進展する契機となった。
sen.e: Sato's interpretation of Takauji as a ruler in the lord-and-vassal relationship was one example, which afforded an opportunity to develop a study of the samurai government.
Sato's interpretation of Takauji as a ruler in the lord-and-vassal relationship was one example, which afforded an opportunity to develop a study of the samurai government.

sen.j: 現代の歴史研究において、尊氏を逆賊とする見解は存在せず、むしろ尊氏が逆賊となるまでの経過が歴史研究の一テーマになることもある。
sen.e: In today's history study, nobody interprets Takauji as a traitor any more, and the process of Takauji's becoming a traitor sometimes can be a theme of historical study.

sen.j: 文化面においても、吉川英治が昭和30年代に書いた『私本太平記』は尊氏を主人公としているが読者に広く受け入れられており、尊氏への評価が戦前のものから大きく変化していることがわかる。
sen.e: "Shihon Taiheiki" written by Eiji YOSHIKAWA in Showa 30's had set Takauji as a main character, and accepted by many readers, which suggested that not only the political but also the cultural view of Takauji had shifted very much compared with that before WWII.

"Shihon Taiheiki" written by Eiji YOSHIKAWA in the late 1950s had Takauji as a main character, and was accepted by many readers, which suggested that not only the political but also the cultural view of Takauji had shifted very much compared with that before WWII.

"Shihon Taiheiki" written by Eiji YOSHIKAWA in the late 1950s had Takauji as a main character, and was accepted by many readers, which suggested that not only the political but also the cultural view of Takauji had shifted very much compared with that before WWII.

sen.j: 京都国立博物館所蔵の『騎馬武者像』は尊氏の肖像として一般に知られていたが、2代将軍足利義詮の花押が像上部に据えられていることや、騎馬武者の馬具に描かれている輪違の紋が足利氏の家紋ではないこと（高氏の家紋が輪違）などの理由から、足利家執事高師直あるいはその子の高師詮の肖像とする説が有力視されており、現在では尊氏説は否定されている。
sen.e: "Kibamusha zo (means a portrait of warrior on the horse back)" preserved in the Kyoto National Museum was generally known as a portrait of Takauji, but now considered to be a portrait of Ko no Moronao, the regent of the Ashikaga clan, or that of Ko no Moroakira, son of Moronao. It's because there's a decorative signature of the 2nd shogun Yoshiakira on the upper part of the body, and the family crest of the two rings described on the warrior's harness was not the Ashikaga family's, but the KO family's.

"Kibamusha zo" (a portrait of warrior on the horse back), preserved in the Kyoto National Museum, was generally known as a portrait of Takauji, but is now considered to be a portrait of KO no Moronao, the regent of the Ashikaga clan, or that of KO no Moroakira, son of Moronao. It's because there's a decorative signature of the 2nd shogun Yoshiakira on the upper part of the body, and the family crest of the two rings described on the warrior's harness was not the Ashikaga family's, but the KO family's.
sen.cmt: moved quotation mark; deleted "means"; added commas; capitalized "KO"; deleted extra space
sen.e: "Kibamusha zo" (a portrait of warrior on the horse back), preserved in the Kyoto National Museum, was generally known as a portrait of Takauji, but is now considered to be a portrait of KO no Moronao, the regent of the Ashikaga clan, or that of KO no Moroakira, son of Moronao. It's because there's a decorative signature of the 2nd shogun Yoshiakira on the upper part of the body, and the family crest of the two rings described on the warrior's harness was not the Ashikaga family's, but the KO family's.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代に藤原隆信が描いたとされる国宝神護寺三像のうち伝平重盛像は、平重盛を描いたものと考えられてきたが、1990年代半ばに美術史家の米倉迪夫や黒田日出男らによって尊氏像であるとの説が提示され、広い支持を集めている。
sen.e: Portrait of Taira no Shigemori, one of the Jingo-ji san zo, painted by FUJIWARA no Takanobu in Kamakura period, had been considered a portrait of Shigemori TAIRA, but Michio YONEKURA and Hideo KURODA claimed that it is a portrait of Takauji, and now this interpretation is widely accepted.
sen.cmt: 神護寺三像の対訳からThree portrait paintings in Jingo-ji削除、平重盛像の対訳からTAIRA no Shigemori zo/Portrait painting of TAIRA no Shigemori削除
sen.e: Portrait of Taira no Shigemori, one of the Jingo-ji san zo, painted by FUJIWARA no Takanobu in Kamakura period, had been considered a portrait of Shigemori TAIRA, but Michio YONEKURA and Hideo KURODA claimed that it is a portrait of Takauji, and now this interpretation is widely accepted.

Portrait of Taira no Shigemori, one of the Jingo-ji san zo, painted by FUJIWARA no Takanobu in Kamakura period, had been considered a portrait of Shigemori TAIRA, but Michio YONEKURA and Hideo KURODA claimed that it is a portrait of Takauji, and now this interpretation is widely accepted.

sen.j: 等持院所蔵の尊氏木像との比較や、冠をとめる笄（こうがい）が室町初期に流行した形状であることなどが根拠として挙げられている。
sen.e: Their opinion bases on the comparison of the portrait with the wooden statue of Takauji preserved in Toji-in, and the popular shape of the hairpin called Kogai to hold the hat in the early Muromachi period.
Their opinion is based on the comparison of the portrait with the wooden statue of Takauji preserved in Toji-in, and the popular shape of the hatpin, called Kogai, used in the early Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: bases->is based; hairpin->hat pin; shorted for clarity
sen.e: Their opinion is based on the comparison of the portrait with the wooden statue of Takauji preserved in Toji-in, and the popular shape of the hatpin, called Kogai, used in the early Muromachi period.

sen.j: 広島県尾道市の浄土寺にも尊氏を描いたとされる肖像画が所蔵されている。
sen.e: There's another portrait of Takauji preserved in Jodo-ji Temple in Onomichi City, Hiroshima Prefecture.
There's another portrait of Takauji preserved in Jodo-ji Temple in Onomichi City, Hiroshima Prefecture.
There's another portrait of Takauji preserved in Jodo-ji Temple in Onomichi City, Hiroshima Prefecture.

sen.j: その他、江戸時代に描かれた錦絵に歌川芳虎の「太平記合戦図」（尊氏、兵庫・福海寺に避難する図）、橋本周延の「足利尊氏兵庫合戦図」（尊氏、兵庫・福海寺に避難する図）がある。
sen.e: In addition to that, there are some ukiyoe pictures in which Takauji was described: "Taiheiki Kassenzu" made by Yoshitora UTAGAWA, "Ashikaga Takauji Hyogo Kassenzu" made by Chikanobu HASHIMOTO. Both paintings are deal with Takauji sheltering in the Jodo-ji Temple in Hyogo Prefecture.

In addition to that, there are some ukiyoe pictures of Takauji: "Taiheiki Kassenzu", by Yoshitora UTAGAWA; and "Ashikaga Takauji Hyogo Kassenzu", by Chikanobu HASHIMOTO. Both paintings deal with Takauji sheltering in the Jodo-ji Temple in Hyogo Prefecture.

sen.j: また、現代になって作られた銅像が足利市鑁阿寺参道と京都府綾部市安国寺町に設置されている。
sen.e: Also the bronze statues of Takauji were made lately; one is placed on the approach to the Bunna-ji Temple in Ashikaga City, and the other is in Ankokuji Town, Ayabe City, Kyoto Prefecture.
